The first season of Gate is interesing.
The story is quite original mixing nowadays military forces facing mediaval armies. As a passionate of militar armament, I mut say that this show is really accurate in terms of modern strategies. Every vehicle you see here is real and it is used by the Japan Self-Defense Forces (JSDF). BUT, you will not see action in every chapter. There is a lot of politics, negotiations and humor in the story (just like in Star Wars: The Phantom Menace). And I feel that a bit of nationalism is not bad... But here you can see the JSDF beating the American,Chinsese and Russian special operations, which is quite ridiculous. It is not a flawless story but definitely enjoyable if you are patient and/or if you are into modern warfare and fantasy.

8.


In the other hand, the show gives us an spectacular animation. Two dimensional characters in sketchy background and three dimensional animated vehicles may sound awful... But it makes the show even more interesting to watch. For me, this aspect is just perfect.

10.


The sound aspect is important when you are trying to make a modern day armament related show, and this show doesn't fail. Realistic sound effects mixed with the typical sounds you can hear in every anime (and we all love), BUT unfortunately in seems that they had no resources to work in sound quality. Old fashion stereo is not good when the rest of the series is in a HQ level of sound. The opening song is average, nothing you will remember when you finish the season; the real magic comes when the orchestral music starts to sound in the background while the JSDF is kicking asses in another dimension. From the Kanochi Nite theme, to a mix between opera and Richard Wagner's "The Ride of the Walkyries"... The music makes everything in this show epic and... Mhm... Badass.

9.


The characters are the funniest element of Gate. The simple interaction between someone like you from this moder world and someone from a medieval famtastic world. The development is not much for the main protagonist, Itama, but it is very notorious in the rest of the cast. Every character suffers from the colateral effects of the war, so you will see them get over most of the bad situations in the series.

9.


As I said before, Gate has many kinds of interactions... But they get boring sometimes and makes you cringe sometimes with the typical "let's go shopping and make publicity for Japan" scenes. Even so, the action is just a demostration of... Mhm... Badassery. The camera angles, the colors, the realism of how a medieval army would end in front of a contemporary army (spoiler alert: the get destroyed). The action scenes here are something you will watch more than just once.

8.


Overall, this anime is interesting and a bit of an experiment that I really enjoyed. The last episode leaves you wanting more (and that's what you actually get). So, if you are into extensive dialogue added between action scenes, then this anime is for you!

I started watching this because of how apparently "popular" it is, or rather how much it was talked about. I heard it was extreme with wish fulfillment and fanservice(not THAT fanservice, but it still did THAT at least at one point).
Story 4/10: About as lackluster and wish fulfillment as it gets. A mysterious greek/roman architectural building just shows up out of nowhere perfectly placed in the middle of a Japanese street in the relative area of an anime/manga/doujin... Otaku event. No explanation whatsoever, and nobody even comments on how such a structure perfectly placed itself in the center of a Japanese road. It wasn't toobig or suspiciously small. It wasn't angled in any way. But exactly in the middle of the street between buildings perfectly aligned with the road, with enough space for Japanese to enclose it with their own building.


Every nation other than Japan is played to be thoroughly bad guys. It also frequently hops off topic to show how people love the JSDF/Japan for invading their world, killing hundreds of thousands, and literally causing civil wars and secessionist uprisings in nearby countries via their actions. These people are also the same refugees that fell victim to said events... But they ignore that and show that the JSDF and Japan always do the right thing.


Art 7/10: The most redeeming factor of the show is in it's art, which in itself is a telltale problem since even bad and/or terrible animes can have great animation budgets and studios backing them. However most of the time you are simply looking at scenery or opinionated conversations between characters on dull backgrounds. The only action is when it is dramatically overdone to propaganda levels to stroke the JSDF's ego. Showing the "Military Might" of the JSDF by gunning/bombing/knife fighting iron-age soldiers using spears with no effort at all. In fact I don't think a single JSDF soldier was even injured in this first season.


Sound 6/10: It was good when it mattered, but seemed lackluster and overdone at times.


Character 5/10: Some characters were well made, mainly 2 of the 3 girls in the cast this season(not Rory) and another character that shows up at the end to get Itami's help. Of which Itami is a downright terrible character because of the sheer amount of wish fulfillment they forced into him.


His squad is full of completely hollow characters, and the only one to actually get any sort of depth to their character seemed to be the most reasonable choice for a love interest. But there was virtually no interaction between her and Itami outside of Comedy. And Itami himself is surrounded by underage fantasy girls while basically choosing to be forever alone for the sake of being an Otaku. Doin your parents proud, Itami.


Enjoyment 6/10: For the first season it's relatively enjoyable. At least until you read between the lines or notice the reoccurring themes. Of which is obviously using as much "Fan Favourite" things in the anime/source material as they can to try and appeal to as much audience as possible... and of course what seems to be Japanese Propaganda.


Overall 5/10: Not awful by any means, but it isn't remotely the best thing I've ever seen. It lacks any real depth to virtually all characters outside of maybe 3 "side" characters, and focus's too much on showing how "awesome" Japan and the JSDF are... Constantly. All while avoiding any real sense or realistic reactions to such events occurring.

This Review Applies to Both Seasons
Although this anime has an interesting concept, and a pretty well done realistic storyline, it does feel too much like propaganda. (The video review is up on my channel, here is the written)
Story - 7/10
The premise of this anime, is that there is GATE which appeared out of nowhere and opened in Japan. Now invaders from the other side of the Gate started attacking Japan, little do they know, they have invaded a world that is far beyond them, and they get destroyed by the Japan Self-Defence Forces. Yes it is the modern technology of world vs. a fantasy medievalworld, so in short its Guns vs Swords, and that’s not going to turn out well for one side, at least. And so follows the story of Itami Youji of the JSDF and Japan trying to form a peace treaty with the world beyond the Gate. 


The pacing of this anime feels kind of weird. At times it will feel fast, on flowing fine, but there are also times when the pacing just feels slow and drags on. GATE feels likes a war drama, as even though we do follow one of the main characters, there are multiple stories within the anime that play different parts in the whole entire plot. And when there is too many stories, there is quite a few that few rush and incomplete, in fact that is what happened to some of the stories in GATE. Some of the side story is completely forgotten and left out leaving you wondering, what actually happened. And the problem comes in during the second half, when it was a really long drag to the finale and they didn’t really completed it properly, there was so many things left undone, because they focused too much time on one thing, the other is swept to the side. The storyline in general, starts out as an adventure, but soon becomes a political story involving the government of both factions. 


Characters - 7/10


Itami Youji is the main character of the show, and he is the one we follow the most. On the surface he is just an otaku just trying to read doujinishi. But in actuality he is a First Lieutenant of the JSDF, and a really highly regarded one at that. However he does imply he is only in the military because it pays well, and he can use that pay check to fund his otaku life, which he would preferably prioritize. Over the course of the show, we get to know a little more about his character, but unfortunately we don’t see a lot of development from him, for the reason being, he always seems to know what to do. There is a slight development around the middle, when he decides to do what’s right than just follow orders, but even that was kind of really done very quickly. Itami pretty just follows orders half the time and is there to represent a soldier, who is caught in everything, including his own harem.


Speaking of his Harem, there are 3 main girls who are part of it; Lelei, Tuka and Rory. Rory who is best girl probably gets the least amount of attention during the show, but she makes up for it for her badassery. Lelei gets some subtle development, as she learns more about the human world she applies her knowledge to help Itami, and is sort of a translator for the JSDF. Tuka probably gets the most attention out of the main girls of the harem, being very fragile at first, not accepting her reality, comes around later to see reality. These characters are pretty much around to fill out Itami’s fantasy harem, which he gains.


Another character that needs some mention is Pina co Lada, yes she sounds like a cocktail. She plays a major part of the peace treaty, as she saw the difference in strength between her army and Japan’s and rather than having a pointless conflict, she is searching for peace between the two countries for the good of her own country. And she would probably get the most development in the show as she learns about Japan, but also learning about her own country and learning how to be a leader. 

There is a lot of characters in GATE, because there is a lot of stories. There are few characters that get quite a bit of attention and some that don’t as much. Which really bugs me because some characters’ stories get forgotten, when they felt like they were going somewhere. Especially at the end when some stories just concluded very abruptly and conveniently. What I do like about the characters are their interactions with each other. Seeing the two worlds connect can lead to entertaining and interesting conversations. And I like how all the characters are rather likeable, and the ones you hate, you really hate. 


Animation and Sound - 7/10, 8/10


I expected decent standard A-1 animation for this show, and it delivers in that aspect. The art style is rather standard, most the animation is smooth, and they look fine. If you look closely, it does look like the art style was pencil drawn and coloured, because you see slight pencil line marks in the backgrounds and characters. What did bother me were the dragon scenes in the show, when a far the dragon would not look right, it doesn’t look part of that world. The shooting effects is fine, it can be really flashy of course. What impressed me the most was some the magic used in the world, and when a spell or a field starting lightning up, it would like amazing. 


The OST is fine for what it is. It is a nice mixture of fantasy and military music. You get quite a few strings here and there. The OP has a nice rock vibe track to, which gives you a conflict and adventure vibe. However the ED is completely different, it’s a more pop track featuring the main 3 girls singing the tracks. It’s a nice catchy dance track and I love it, but there are times during the anime when it would end of a gritty or tense cliff-hanger, and suddenly some happy pop music starts playing, which completely kills the vibe. The sound effects in the show is quite good, the sounds of bullets vs swords really shows us that these are two different worlds conflicting with each other. 


Enjoyment - 8/10


I much rather enjoyed the concept of GATE. It was an interesting idea, mixing the two worlds together and putting it in a realistic setting, by getting the politics and military involved. However I wish the story was a bit faster, because at times it will drag and you just want to see how the 2 worlds interact with each other more, which was the most thing I enjoyed about the show. Seeing the 2 worlds react to each other’s culture. But there is one major problem I find with this anime, and that is, it’s TOO one sided. Everything is completely in favour of the JSDF. They can literally do no wrong, in the show, they never feel like they are in trouble at any given time in the show. Except when they were facing a dragon, but that was short lived. And it kind of annoys me because its propaganda, they want to show how great the military is, but it doesn’t lead to great story telling, because there is false suspense. Like I said the most enjoyment of this show is seeing the 2 worlds interact with each other.


Verdict - 7.5/10


As we draw closer to the end of the review, I give the story a 7. It has an really interesting concept and executes in main plot rather well with its realistic story. But the pacing can be off at times and there were a lot of different stories, which feel forgotten. 


For the animation and sound, I give it a 7 and 8. The animation and art style is standard for A-1, and the pencil style sort of works, but I was never really wowed by many things except the magic. The dragon looked like it didn’t belong in the world. The soundtrack is fine and does a good job of mixing the 2 genres together. The OP is pretty good and the ED is really nice catchy, but it can kill the vibe sometimes at the end of a tense episode.


For the characters I give it a 7. There is a lot of likeable characters in the show, with slight development for every character. And that is still impressive, for such a huge cast. But some of them are left forgotten, unfinished and rushed. I do like the character interactions, but I felt like there could’ve been more.


For my own personal enjoyment, I give it a 8. I was really interested in the concept and hooked into the world. I enjoyed watching the two worlds interact and learn about one another. However, it felt too one sided for me to really be suspense of anything during the time this anime was aired, it’s kind of predictable.


So for the overall score of GATE, I give it a 7.5.10 after round it all up. I recommend this show to people who love military genre or those who love fantasy, or people who like watching alternative dimensions, because this is probably for you.

Okay, so from what I've seen I believe this was supposed to be 25 episodes, and the ending of the last episode seems to support this. It's a hook for a second season that I hope happens, because this is a very interesting concept that I want to see explored further.
So, basic premise of the story (that you can find above mostly) is that the Japanese military is sent through a Gate to a fantasy world after the fantasy world attacks ours. From here the military save a few people, and our otaku protagonist i sent through. This anime doesn't try to hid the factthat it's partly a harem between three fantasy girls, but it does not focus on that like Monster Musume (not bagging it, just don't compare them).


However, the story goes a lot deeper. It goes into the politics and some interesting ideas like how Japan deals with other countries who are greedy and want their share of the other world. Sounds boring, but anyone who has watched either Spice and Wolf or Maoyuu Maou Yuusha would know that it's not. 


Anyway, art. It's not anything groundbreaking but there is something about it that feels more mature, other than the fact that the MC isn't a teenager in high-school like most anime of this kind. I don't know, but they got a lot right in the visuals that I don't know how to describe, it's not awkwardly bright like some anime, and it's nothing unique like Zankyou no Terror, but there is the polish that just works.


Okay, so the sound is something that I've began to take notice of recently a lot more since the aforementioned Zankyou no Terror, as well as Code Geass and (don't shoot me for saying this) Fairy Tail. I used to only pay attention to the OP and ED for this section, but there wasn't anything that stood out for me during the show. The music was great at setting the mood, but there was nothing like Is or Von from ZnT or The Dark Guild Theme from FT. (Andi realised after this that I didn't mention Cowboy Bebop or Baccano, but I haven't actually watched them even if I love the soundtracks, plus they are on a different planet entirely).


The characters are what really make this anime shine. Sure, you have your standard fantasy staples like magicians, elves, humans and various human animal cross-breeds, but they are unique characters in their own right. And god help me if I don't praise this anime for having MCs that AREN'T TEENAGERS!!! Sure the guy is still an otaku, as are some of his friends (and this one old guy) and the audience can relate to him when he talks about waifus and memorizing OPs, but he ISN'T a dumb teenager. And stemming off this not all the characters in the faux-harem are generic. The mage is interested in our society (and she becomes freaking awesome because of chemistry), the elf has some interesting PTSD, and Rory... well... Rory is...

So, the other side characters all have their own unique charm. Princess Pina Co Lada (I legit replayed that scene to check I didn't hear that wrong) isn't your standard princess, especially when she discovers... well...

And then you have the other military characters, specifically Takeo and Shino. Takeo is a fellow otaku to Itami who provides some much needed otaku banter  between the characters. Meanwhile Shino is the strong headed one who provides some really great banter as well as well as ideas. There is one more character (who I won't spoil) who is adorable and awesome.


Finally, how i enjoyed it. It was bloody great, but I was lead to believe there would be 25 eps, not twelve. And the final episode shows that. the last lines are legitimately (spoilers I think, but not really) "It's only been half a year..." Yea... even the show acknowledges that... I wish there was more because there were some plotlines developing in the last episode that I'm just praying for a season 2.


Anyway, I think this show is a great show in the Fantasy genre, and instead of going in pretending it's not a harem (*cough* SAO *cough), it makes you think it's a harem when it's not really. I give it an almost killing a dragon with a rocket launcher but not quite/10 because of that ending that just feels unsatisfying.

This one is clearly among the best anime of the Summer 2015 season. The story is fairly original, involving a gate opening up between Tokyo and a fantastical world where dragons, monsters, elves, and others exist. It all starts with an invasion by the army from this parallel world, and soon we get an army of Japanese soldiers going over to the special region in an effort of recognizance. 
The clash of word generates plenty of interesting and funny situations. There are a myriad of awesome characters to appreciate and learn to understand. Among these, we have one of my favorite characters in an animeever, Rory Mercury.


The series does a very good job in blending in some political situations that engage our attention, and of course there is a little fan service here and there too (like the vast majority of series today), but this is kept in check and does not take away anything from the enjoyment of the series.


I found the animation to be very good and there is a lot of creativity displayed in some of the characters creation. Overall, a very nice, well-rounded series. There is a little bit of an issue with the fact that it feels like we only got half a season, with another 12 episodes coming in January 2016, but it is understandable.

GATE is an anime with a premise that far exceeds the actual execution. 
    While the show is not brimming with originality, the foundation is solid.  Like many contemporary shows, the protagonist is thrown into a fantasy world, but it is not virtual and the stakes are much higher because of it.  This is not an RPG.  There are thousands of lives at stake on both ends of the spectrum.  
    Unfortunately, the show tends to gloss over its more serious issues.  Violence is portrayed in a way that lacks emotional impact.  Theshow glorifies the JSDF mowing down the soldiers and bandits of the other world, which can admittedly be fun to watch.  However, not one JSDF soldier is painted in a negative light.  There is no sexism among the JSDF’s ranks.  They do not leave behind any villagers to save themselves.  None of their killings are unjustified.  There is practically nothing wrong with the JSDF while the other world’s inhabitants are often dehumanized because of their technological and governmental inferiority.


    The other world’s “bad guys” tend to act so stereotypically that they are often scheming, have an evil sneer on their face, or both at some point.  The worst of the modern world tends to be anyone not Japanese.  In a sense, the world building is not the strongpoint of this show.  That leads to the viewer feeling almost no sympathy or connection to the other world’s population, aside from the few characters that follow around the protagonist.


    As for that aspect, the main cast of characters are why anybody should be watching.  Of course, the ones following the protagonist are female.  The youngest is the most soft spoken, while the oldest tends to be the most bold.  That is commonplace.  Fortunately all of them are interesting characters with unique attributes that make them fun to watch.  One of them is an apostle with superhuman abilities, another is a mage, while the other is a high elf.  And yes, they are all “cute.”  If any of these characters were to disappear, the show would not work as well as it does.  That includes the protagonist, Itami, who tends to keep everyone together.  


    The art is fine if a bit bland at times.  Nothing really stands out except for the terrible CGI dragon that rears its head every so often.  This is a show that someone should watch for its cast of characters and not its story.  It is a fun break in between something else far more serious, and it does a damn good job at that.

My honest thoughts. I came into this thinking it would be super lame and an immense invasion by modern tech. But this was surprisingly awesome and full of heart The characters are well developed and I love the way they speak Japanese slow when trying to speak the other language. It almost feels like a cool anime to prop up the real JSDF and how they act in real life. As ex-military who lived in Japan for 10 years, this is honestly how they actually are. Really good people who uphold human rights. As for the rest of the anime, I really like the artstyle and the concept of the story. If you like military and/or fantasy, this is the perfect mash-up. It even has some romance intertwined. Looking forward to watching season 2!

A decent watch with tempered expectations.
The story holds up well and has a clear sense of direction. It's just not strong enough to support side plots or in depth backstories. 
Gate has a pretty vivid color scheme that is quite nice to look at. Nothing really stands out as far as characters or animation is concerned.
Opening sounds good enough. No problems with voice lines or sound effects.
There's a lot of characters. The problem with having lots of characters is that they need a lot of time to flesh out each one. This just isn't possible in 12 episodes. I found myself liking the characters, butwanting more development and depth. \n\n
Gate performed equally well in all categories, but excelled in none. Humor and action are present but not in enough quantity to carry the show. It takes equal parts of each area to prop the show up. A conglomeration of genres and themes rather than a singular aspect to watch.\n\n
tl;dr average

GATE: JIEITAI KANO CHI NITE KAKU TATAKAERI SEASON 1 ANIME REVIEW
OVERALL: 9
PLOT: 9/10
What if there is a world other than our world? What if there are living beings we don't know of? What if a portal from another world will pop out of nowhere and an unknown kind of which we hardly imagine starts to flash in our eyes? That is what this series show us. It is not your typical protagonist who's been teleported in another world. It is not also something like being stuck in a game where there are no means to escape. Not also the type of protagonist who's born withsuperior talents or been given a power to outdo the rest. It also tackles the economic decisions a society will make when a new people adds up, a new location or continent or a world has been identified. How they start anew. How other country thinks of a way to get the better ones. How the greed of peope will possibly destroy a good opportunity of humankind.


CHARACTER: 9/10


The main character of this story is somewhat normal. Normal in a way that he has his hobbies, his love for his priorities. His craving for things he decided is important in his life. He is not the common prince charming like face nor the charismatic one. He is also not the kind of super intelligent, cool kind of guy who dismissed any conversation he don't find useful. He's a kind hearted guy, using his mind to think rationally. He's lazy most of the time, but one of his priority is to help mankind. He has skills that he manage to get through hardship. He is humble and humane. In line with the other characters, well yeah, most of the anime now always have a loli character. I guess that is also a norm.


VOICE AND ANIMATION: 9/10


The animation is great and I think that is normal. What I mean normal is the common animation these days. The emotions was well written in the face of the characters, as well as the things around them. The actions taken place is also expressed successfully. And I don't have any comment with the sounds since it is also fine. I'm really thinking about Itami. I know there is another anime character who looks like him. I just can't remember who it is.


ENJOYMENT: 10/10


I enjoyed it, yes. The concept of the series is unique for me. It is literally reverse than other stories. The actions and thinking of the characters are shocking and also comes from a different view. It is fun to watch since the protagonist is an otaku, you can quite relate to the feelings he show along the series.


ENDING: 8/10


The ending is, of course, a cliffhanger. There is a season 2of it which I haven't watch it yet. There is more to come and the story is just getting started. The only thing I'm kinda disappointed or must we say kinda expected is for the protagonist to show his other skills. Something like combat skills. I want him to show off more, to show us another expression of his own, to help us know him more. Well, maybe in the next season. But overall, yeah. This anime is worth watching.

To be clear, I only watched 5 episodes of the first season, so keep that in mind as to whether you find my review valuable or not.
The premise of GATE is amazing, and it starts off solid in the first episode. And then it quickly devolves into a showcase of the two worst anime tropes: Japanese hyper-nationalist jingoism, and loli-girl harem.
Had these show handled its invaders from another world theme more seriously, it would have been a damn fine show. Instead, no one in this universe behaves like a real person, or is realistic in any sense of the word. The entire purpose of theseries is to show off how great Japan is and how idiotic the rest of the world is.\n\n
Oh, and it lets young dudes watching it imagine that they are the main character, surrounded by cute underage-looking girls that fawn over him constantly.\n\n
It's just sick, and very emblematic of where anime is right now, which is a bad place.

This is the kind of anime we should be demanding! This series justifies paying for anime! It's got everything that a fan of anime could want. Action, emotion, comedy, suspense, intrigue, sexiness, science, etc. All the characters are solid and fill their roles well. So stop reading this review and watch it. Seriously, anime like this doen't come along every day so go check it out. Okay, I should point out that this series is not for every one. It's portrayal of women leaves something to be desired. They're all painted as victim at one point or another. Except Shino Kuribayashi & Rory Mercury. Twowomen who easily hold their own on a battlefield. This series is also about the horror of war, so it's violent and depicts it. As it should it is a war story after all. People die in war, it's a simple fact. So I tend to loathe series featuring war where the human toll isn't made clear to both us and the characters. Other than that it's an anime for everyone (well if the SOLE reason you watch anime is moe girls or supernatural bishonen then mebe not everyone). I'd even suggest a few of my non anime friends watch it, but not with their kids though. Yeah this ones not for the kids.

Well, this is one of those unusual productions that actually kicks off a whole lot of UNUSUAL things in the MOST UNUSUAL ways, and it works fine for me.
This is not your usual yet still VERY familiar plot-lined anime. Never mind the propaganda and whatnot, it's all about how different we all have different ways to interpret things. Most people say it's the typical OLD VS NEW route, well, all I see is Science vs Fantasy [I mean, dragons exist in medieval times (lol)? That's news to me.]. It's like watching 2 genres fighting each other yet both want to make peace (Hate-Love.... Oh wait,Tsundere is way better to describe it AND I DEFINITELY LOVE EM.). Eherm.... M'kay, here's is what I can say about this series.


Story - 9: Given that this is an almost untouched plot route (Kinda, since Outbreak Company also uses the same Initial plot LITERALLY), I can't judge much without proper reference, BUT!!!, even if it's unknown to me, the tension and full-blown one-sided power balance left an undeniably UNBIASED point of view on the story's situation. Ignoring the propaganda-like feeling (Well, the JSDF IS the Protagonist force in the story, it's obvious it would feel like one), Guns beat Swords and Rockets beat Dragons combination is the MOST STRAIGHTFORWARD slap in the face for those who love fantasy, and I bet it felt good.


Art - 8: Not much to say. I did like the |C/Slide in| kind of display where different angles of characters can be seen without much of a change in the frames itself, but it did leave a lacking feeling when it comes to group to 1 character conversations. Aside from that and repeated parts, it's good. Oh, and I gave points to the Opening's art design (Personal points). I actually liked it (Personally).


Sound - 8: Aside from gun shots and bone crackles (Which I like), everything was ok. The Opening song fits the art design. If anything, I wanted to hear more bones breaking (But I guess that's almost impossible since they die before they can even move a meter closer to the Jieitai).


Character - 8: The MOST mysterious character in this anime is the MC itself. I won't spoil so all I can say is that him, even though an otaku, being a "Unique"-type of soldier was unexpected and quite a laughable surprise. It didn't add to anything but it still made him kinda special in ways a normal MC, with above-average intelligence or fast reflexes, will look like crap. Aside from the elf being useless, the other characters, including the squad members of the MC, where all good tier.


Enjoyment - 10: Having a pretty unbalanced war playing out, the one sided massacre was, in a sense, quite an amusing idea (*Cringe* I feel like I'm turning into a Psycho). Just kidding. It was that reality-like balance that gave the anime a bit of excitement. 'Fantasy never stood a chance to Science' -like theme gave birth to the idea of what was right. 'If the science side wanted to wipe out or forcefully conquer the fantasy side, they could in mere minutes, so why not?', this question is the real point I wanted to watch in the whole series to the very end, and I personally enjoyed it much.


Overall - 9: I'd say this is one I might never forget (I wish I could so I would re-watch it). It's not the best for all since there are people who see this as propaganda or people who hate the one-sided war, but it still gives an idea of why absolute power isn't the best solution to solving conflicts.

I'll keep it brief.  
This show is really good.  If you just want to sit back and watch a really fun and interesting show, you're looking in the right place.
Story:
Most of the story is seeing how a fantasy civilization is exposed to the today's advanced military technology.  It's a pleasure seeing how they interact.  (i.e. the funny moments where people call war vehicles "iron elephants or iron Pegasuses").  It's pretty rare for anything to really embrace both fantasy and modern themes because most shows are either fantasy, modern, or modern with a little fantasy.
Art:
Art is pretty detailed.  It doesn'tlook low budget at all. 


Sound:

I really like the opening.  It's not something that will stick in your head, but you may think twice before skipping over it each time it plays.  The rest of the show's OST's is just alright.  


Character:

This is probably a weak point in the show. I didn't really find anyone too interesting.  Almost everyone fits some kind of archetype and doesn't really change at all.  Although they're somewhat boring, I found everyone to be likable, including the protagonist.  He's not some whiny kid or a complete loser.  He's actually pretty mature compared to many other anime protagonists. 


Enjoyment: 

I'd say this is one of my favorite shows of the season.  I found that the setting made this show really fun to watch.  That being said, it's no masterpiece, but that's ok.  This show is an example of a show that's just "fun", so I would recommend this to everyone.

Kazuhira's basic as fuq reviews: Gate: Thus the JSDF Fought There!
Story 7 - Great concept and I want more. Can't wait for world building and politics. Several minor plot points were started but not resolved, left me unsatisfied with most character specific stories.
Art 5 - Very inconsistent quality, falls between an 8 and a 4. Serviceable, but I was hoping for better consistency for an anime in 2015. Ughhhh the CG was terrible. I cringed every time.
Sound 5 - No memorable OST whatsoever, lack of catchy OPs or EDs. Generic and totally average.
Characters 6 - Bare bones personality, really there to fill fetishes and requiredstory roles. Nobody memorable outside of Rory. It makes due, just not up to par.\n\n
Enjoyment 7 - Overall an enjoyable anime. Would like to see it expanded on, and will probably watch season 2 to see if Itami and Rory bang.\n\n
Final score 6 -  As a product by its own merits, it falls short of being called good, but my hope is that the franchise will see to some of my gripes in the near future. It's worth the watch if you enjoy military and fantasy as this anime caters to both. If you don't particularly care for either, than I would avoid it. Your time is better spent elsewhere. Season 2 is coming January 2016.

There's a lot to hate about Gate and it certainly has a lot of flaws but good luck expressing them on your way to being charmed the hell out of by this anime.
First, it's definitely a new approach. The typical NEET/otaku about to go into a fantasy world... only our typical NEET otaku also happens to be an exemplary member of Japanese SDF (military). This has the same flaw as "Irregulars" anime where the main good guy is just too strong or too good at what he does. And we're given lame excuses to how they become like that... but rather than spiting the animefor these flaws, I found myself charmed by them.


I also specifically REALLY hated the blonde elf girl. Not only was she both boring and predictable, she got incredibly annoying in the next season at least for me. She's literally there to be a simple eye candy for the elf fanboys.


Thing is I believe this anime is literally propaganda to try to get the male youth wasting away their lives as otakus to join the SDF. This is definitely a shounen but it doesn't play like one; shounen generally have their characters constantly one up a stronger villain every arc without much substance. This however is different. The "protagonist" side is the one with modern military. They can literally take over and wipe out this fantasy world in 1 day if they wanted to. Diplomacy, approaches to unknown culture, and interactions? These are all realistic. Sure it's fantasy world with fantasy characters... but the first few episodes are so identical to Generation Kill and their journey of sitting in humvees through Iraq invasion.

Generally speaking GATE is not something I could recommend (unless you are really into guns/military). The plot is utter bullshit and the characters have no personality whatsoever (except the JSDF guys, those are ALL psychopaths and/or bipolar).
This show turns what was a good premise into a generic harem. Why you ask? Because apparently you give most otakus a bunch of generic girls and some big ass guns and the plot's covered for the most (even if it's blatant propaganda).
Ok, so let's start with what did good:
Art - 8.5:
Let's face it, the animation quality is good, particularly the military equipment. The characters designs are also welldone albeit too generic, you really feel the A-1 look (SAO, A/Z, etc.). The things I found halfheartedly done were the backgrounds that were at times too plain and the color palette used for the characters from the other world as It is one quite overused one.


From here on it goes downhill, REALLY fast


//SPOILERS AHEAD!


Story - 3:

An unknown gate to other world appears in Japan, more precisely the middle of Ginza, Tokyo. From this gate a hellish army comes out, equipped with bronze/iron age weapons and charges in a sudden invasion to Japan. Our MC who was passing nearby going to buy some doujins, gets dragged into the fight of the JSDF and the invaders (cause yeah, we can mobilize an army in nanoseconds). Here we learn he is from the JSDF and we watch him help the useless policemen evacuate people (as a side note, despite the blood-fest surrounding all he can think is lit. "shit, I won't be able to buy my doujins").

Then, after fending off the invasion with surprising ease Japan has to send an Army there but the JSDF can't operate outside Japan, what do we do? We declare the other world part of Japan (cause we can). What do we do there? Massacre 'em all, we have to slaughter at least 100k or they won't take us seriously.

Ok so far it's not so bad right, It may have a couple of issues but It's still decent. Except it's not cause apparently everyone belonging to the JSDF (which by the way aren't real soldiers, when they are off work they are not considered military, plus they have pretty much never taken part in real combat) are first rate soldiers. They are more skilled than any operatives from all countries with an active army (US, Russia, China) and have the "right" set of morals and therefore are the "good guys".

I mean yeah, they couldn't say "As a response from hogging the gate the Americans cut out all the weapon sales to Japan" or "by agreement of the 3 superpowers they decide to: 

invade Japan and secure the gate".

or

blast the gate with a Nuke".

or

kill the people with a Neutron Bomb and leave the gate intact."

but still the OPness of the JSDF is...


In short: Japan vs The World (Japan is the good guy) = Japan Wins


PS: The EU doesn't exist apparently in this setting.


PS2: Global peaceful negotiations don't exist either.


PS3: There's a complete reenacting of Apocalypse Now (They even play Ride of The Valkyries).


Charcters - 3:

The characters are pretty basic, an otaku deadbeat who's a 1st Lieutenant in the JSDF who puts a front of being a laze ass and is in fact quite skilled. This guy who gets his dream come true of having his own harem is in fact a psychopath as every 

 other operative of the JSDF. This guys despite having close to null combat experience start massacring tons of people to then go to eat happily together with the non hostile locals. 

It's really crazy, the horrors of war are very well depicted, but our characters seem immune to the effects of it (piles of ravaged corpses, civilian deaths by the thousands, etc). It ends up being a one-sided war/massacre, all the while we are reminded that the JSDF are the "good guys". Even the MCs main ex-wife shows lit. no expression after witnessing the (just killed) dead bodies of 10+ special ops operatives in front of them in her house.

There hasn't been any mention to the girls and well that's because there's not much to talk, It's your usual generic harem cast, the big boobed blonde (elf) who's an airhead, the sadistic and lustful loli and the "I have no personality" magician girl plus an empire's sheltered princess (with knight complex) that after brief contact suddenly develops an extreme liking to Yaoi (cause yeah Yaoi manga is that good apparently, I should read some). Hell, if the people from this world understood/liked Japanese culture like the other world characters, otakus wouldn't be considered that strange of a thing.


Sound - 6:

No special songs nor I like the OP/ED, It's rated this high solely because the seiyuus aren't half bad.


Enjoyment - 5:

As much as It pains me to admit I like guns (not enough to be a gun maniac

but enough to enjoy the battle scenes even if they are ridiculous). What I regret is the lack of newer airplanes (i.e F-15J, F2, etc) but well whatever.


Overall - 5:

In a way I think maybe I'm being to harsh but at the same time I think I'm being to lenient. It's impossible to overlook the propaganda, sure If you don't care or you are just a diehard japan supremacist this may hit in the right spot but It doesn't sit right with me. Disregarding this fact that the situation is so unrealistic that one starts thinking: why even try to put politics? hell, had they done what most anime do (First try a peaceful approach, to at least make them look like the "good guys" and pretend the world is comprised of Japan and a great... sea?) It could've been better.


TL;DR: Watch this if you are a diehard war/weapons fan and don't care about plot but don't expect tactics or strategy, we are talking about brute force only here

(Or if you are one of those people that can enjoy anything as long as it has boobs, an elf or a loli on it).

Gate: Jieitai Kanochi nite, Kaku Tatakaeri is where the present day and the fantasy world collides. Literally.
Having a gate that provides entry to both sides was an interesting watch. With all the stories about how this was supposed to be propaganda for the SDF and all that, it doesn't matter. Purely as an anime point of view, every episode went by as a flash and left me wanting more.
Given that I'm only a starter anime fan, I was happy I picked this title to complete. Obviously the real world's firepower and might would overwhelm the fantasy world, but I saw how much potential the animecan have (although it won't be too late for the production company to follow through with more seasons). With the premise of how differently life is with the advance of technology in the present day, we could have seen more of the understanding between the fantasy world and the SDF and society in present day Japan as a whole: differences, similarities and all the fundamentals of life.


The writers can also pursue more towards the politics of Japan and the other countries towards the importance of the new land and the potential of newer resources and raw materials they could find in the other world (there's a town full of magicians and a big-ass red fire dragon around, we can assume that the raw materials can be used in the development of nuclear power, etc).


Which leads to the next agenda: Magic. Loads of magicians, deities and demigods, etc? There were people complaining that the SDF were OP towards the Imperial army - there's so much potential to getting the battles in a bigger scale - imagine sorcerers and a demigod against riflemen (seriously, I'm pretty sure I can count the small number of casualties in the SDF's side, could've added more depth with a higher amount of wounded or even deaths in the soldiers' ranks.


But all in all, I had fun. This was the whole purpose of catching this anime. So many holes can be filled, and yes since it was a harem, we still needed to see the interactions between the MC and the girls right? I mean, if there wasn't the whole dynamic of the anime would've been different. And I probably wouldn't be this much of a fan. Enjoy, everyone.

A mystical gate to another world opens up, and out pours an army of tedious genre bullshit.
GATE's choice to make the Earthlings far more powerful than the fantasy nations should, in principle, have been an interesting one. Combat is consistently one of the most boring and decadently overstylized elements of anime. Instead of a digestible through-line – the reckless charge gradually disintegrates under unanswerable fire, the duelist affects a false opening to bait a real one from his opponent – anime usually gives us visual noise, "badass" dialogue, and arbitrary "dramatic" violation of the author's own, self-devised rules. Taking any of prospect military defeat offthe table at the outset could have created an opening for more absorbing sources of tension. It's a culturally and diplomatically fraught situation, a kind of super-Colombian Exchange in a present-day context complete with modern communications, mass media, democratic politics and great-power competition. Rich and rewarding stories might have been told.


Instead we get a bunch of completely pointless "battle" scenes. Numerous one-sided massacres are depicted in loving detail; the protagonists make no attempt to deter battle or obtain the enemy's surrender, and the antagonists obligingly charge into meaningless death for no reason. After a while, the writers seem to become aware that this is a problem, and start reaching for ways to place the protagonists in genuine danger. Unfortunately they're absolutely terrible at it. Small, isolated patrols travel through hostile territory for no reason and run into completely predictable trouble. At one point the protagonist's motor convoy is held up, literally, by mounted knights pointing lances through the opened windows of their Toyotas; instead of flooring it and scattering the opponents, he gets out of the truck to "negotiate" and is promptly and predictably captured.


The problem with GATE is not that it's militant nationalist propaganda. Some of the unquestioned masterpieces of 20th century film are militant nationalist propaganda. The problem with GATE is that it's narratively incoherent. Events happen for no reason other than plot convenience and characters act with no motivation other than playing to type. Russia, China, and the United States (!) are depicted as jealous international rivals simply because the author doesn't like foreigners. Japan monopolizes access to the gate (isn't it more like an international strait?) and seemingly annexes the entire fantasy world as the "Special Region," but the rival countries don't seem to object or apply any conventional form of pressure against Japan. Instead and for no clear reason they send terrorist hit squads into Japan to be promptly massacred while spouting dialogue along the lines of "Argh! We mere Delta Force operatives are no match for the superior Japanese!"


We're repeatedly assured in dialogue that this nonsensical international struggle revolves around the fantasy world's "strategic resources." We're never shown these resources nor even told what they are until well into the second season; somehow the world knows these resources exist and are extremely important, but not where or what they are. We never meet or even hear about geologists or natural scientists of any kind, nor for that matter linguists, anthropologists, ethnobotanists, or anyone else with a relevant civilian occupation. A demigodess and a powerful mage hang out with the main character yet no-one seems especially interested in investigating the entirely unknown physical principles underlying their abilities, nor does anyone seem bothered by the implications for world religions of a woman claiming divinity and able to manifest miracles at will. One subplot hinges on the Japanese side's complete and explicit disinterest in a large number of dragon scales which we're later told are an organic material comparable to tungsten, one of the hardest and densest materials in existence. The supposedly strategic resources eventually turn out to be mundane cash cows like uranium and petroleum.


Minor details and story beats are just as botched as the big picture. Armaments and military equipment are depicted in loving, autistic detail; meanwhile bare-headed soldiers salute civilians indoors, subordinates unashamedly deprecate superiors, and the commanding officer takes a spontaneous nap in a war zone without telling anyone. One of the soldiers – a 5' redhead with big tits, naturally – is assigned the role of beat-down artist and repeatedly wins unnecessary melee combats with multiple armored opponents twice her size bearing superior weapons. One-off characters are introduced by name in subtitles for no reason, including a stereotypically merchant-looking guy who's there solely to deal in merchandise. The subtitle identifies him as a merchant.


There's just no enjoyable viewing of GATE. As a drama it's one-dimensional, cliché-ridden, and unserious. As a harem comedy it's burdened with boring, tonally inappropriate scenes of massacre and high politics. The animation is mostly unobjectionable but done purely by-the-numbers. Even as right-wing nationalist propaganda, it will repel anyone with the slightest degree of sophistication whatever their politics. It's nothing but trash.

It was (in my opinion) one of the top 5 of this season, even tho I think they wasted a lot of episodes. The main plot advances pretty slowly meanwhile secondary shit happens, but the anime is pretty cool, the concept of a modern army against a fantasy one is really original. the characters were super cool and even tho there wasn't much character development. The battle scenes were rad as fuck, who doesn't love some guns and swords?
anyways... I'm really looking forward the next season, I really wanna see how Itami deals with the red dragon and what happens with the empire... I recallthe king being a fucking douchebag in the first episodes... so yeah... Piña Co Lada is going to have a hard time.

This anime at first glanced looked very appealing to the eye. Its about current military might clashing vs Mid evil times. It had a concept not done regularly and surely was warranted a watch. 
This series at first started of strong but as the episodes went on I gradually got more and more turned off as I watched. This series suffers from wanting to be so much that it failed in mostly everything it set out to accomplish. But at least it succeeded in being good Japaneses propaganda.  
--
Firstly, I never liked one sided series. By that I mean one side is completely moredominant  than the other and its not fun seeing a series where one sided completely dominates the other in every aspect. I at least expected for the Mid-evil kingdoms to form some kind of advantage sometime. Nope! The JSDF(Japanese Self Defense Force) completely demolishes everything it comes against. It was even able to beat the red dragon(which is suppose to be the strongest creature in the other world) with only 3 jeeps and a pair of guns. The JSDF is portrayed as the ultimate fighting group that not even other countries could hope to beat, with scenes of american or Russian soldiers being completely amazed at how good the JSDF is. 


--


Secondly, the characters. The protagonist which is not interesting in the least is given the role of an otaku just for the sake of making him relatable to the fans. This otaku is given the role of lieutenant because why not and goes off into a different world to begin forming his harem. 


The rest of the cast is even weaker. Theres an elf girl which is looking for her dead father but she doesn't want to admit hes dead. This storyline goes nowhere. Theres The Demi-god loli which just drops everything shes doing to go off with the protagonist. Lastly theres a mage that starts to focus more on Science than what her master has been training her for in less than a couple of weeks. The rest of the cast is just there. 


The crew the protagonist assembles are all from the other world which are all incredibly useful but somehow the protagonist in a single episodes befriends them all. These girls alone could give the JSDF a run for their money but they conveniently join sides with the Japanese which are steamrolling through their world. Logic?


Lastly the culture exchange. Thats not presented in this anime. The culture exchange is just the Mid-evil society basking in the glory of how cool and useful the japanese are. 

--


Some of the pros? This series had some moments where some plot points where brought out which where interesting but suddenly discarded. It failed to capitalize on its strong setting and decided to insert more harem moments instead. There was one moment which i liked where the refugee camp the japanese started was solely being turned into a small town by the residents(which are the mid-evil people that lost their homes early in the anime). The Japanese where protecting and shaping this small community and it looked like a place where both worlds life together. This aspect was rarely touched. 


--


Conclusion: This series might give you a good time if you like harem series with not much depth to it. Its an entertaining watch if not much thought is giving to it. If you where looking for a more serious anime then look away but if you where looking for some diehard army anime with explosions, One sided curbstomps and lolis then look no further.

This review contains minor spoilers for both the anime "Gate: Jieitai Kanochi nite, Kaku Tatakaeri", and the movie, "Apocalypse Now".
Rather than writing a complete review of the anime, I wanted to write an analysis of one of the scenes in it and base the review from there. The scene in question would be the famous Ride of the Valkyries scene.
The anime copies from the movie, Apocalypse Now, the scene in which Colonel Kilgore leads a regiment of helicopters to attack a village during the Vietnam war. In Apocalypse Now its the US military against the vietcong, and in Gate, its the JSDF against bandits whohave occupied the town of Italica.


In Gate, the JSDF are completely justified in their assault against their opponent who have terrorized the town and its inhabitants.They are the saviors, the heroes, and the song that they play during their actions, Ride of the Valkyries, brings to mind gallantry and heroism. We see the light of the sun shining behind on them as their two front helicopters dance together going side by side each other. We see and hear the leader of the bandits declaring, "Kill them all" to further emphasize that they are the savages, whereas the JSDF is shown to be professionals who can shoot firearms properly and work together as a team. They are the heroes fighting evil. 


In Apocalypse Now, the US attacks a Vietnamese village with one large ulterior motive. A reward. Kilgore was reluctant at first to do the attack, but once he heard there would be a good surf spot, he's immediately for it. The soldiers even get beer if they do well enough and praise from the commanding officer, Kilgore, that they all look up to and admire. The song that plays during their assault juxtaposes what they believe they are, and what they really are. During the start, with the song playing and the helicopters blaring they are shown heroically going to battle, but we then cut to their adversary. The song is stopped short and we see schoolchildren being led to safety after their teacher hears the helicopters and whats to come with it. They aren't the good fighting the evil, they're bringing the evil.


This is what Gate misses from the Apocalypse now in its copy of the Ride of the Valkyries scene. Art copying from other art is completely fine, but when it is done improperly to the point where stealing is a better term, then there's something wrong. Gate is as pro-war as it can get while it copies from a movie that's completely anti-war. Apocalypse Now shows us a glimpse of the human mind descending into madness during war, while Gate tells us that going to war is fun and can get girls to like you. Gate's version of the Ride of the Valkyries scene is an insult to its original.


This scene alone encapsulates what Gate is. A story about the JSDF bringing justice to this new fantasy world that they've found. In the wars to come, they are the good guys triumphing against evil, with barely any loses with their superior firepower and advanced technology. Their fight isn't difficult or hard, its a simple game where they are always winning. There's no real conflict because we as the audience know for sure that they are going to end up on top. There's no in-depth portrayal of medieval fantasy vs modern military technology, there's only massacre and one-sided victories.
